evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_baseline_t1_early phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during hist_baseline_t1_early is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on available evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in similar incidents involving crew interaction failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t1_early timeframe.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_baseline_t1_early phase.

assumptions: Crew communication via interphone and tug instructor-trainee interaction reflect coordination quality
The pushback beyond TRP and collision indicate coordination failure rather than solely procedural deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without breakdown
If the incident was primarily caused by environmental or marking deficiencies rather than crew coordination

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 documents crew communication and coordination actions and a pushback event with a procedural error, supporting observed communication/coordination breakdown (R2). Discriminators favor R2 over procedural deviation (R1) and marking deficiency (R3).
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from coordination failure

slot_statements.availability: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_baseline_t1_early is present and impacts system operation.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure scenario in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t1_early is resistant to common defeaters and alternative explanations.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t1_early dataset, matching expected failure modes.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_baseline_t1_early is present and impacts system operation.

defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks confirming control malfunction
If mechanical failure was explicitly reported or detected during the event

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H5) shows the pushback was controlled by operators with no indication of mechanical/control failure; the aircraft movement beyond TRP occurred despite engine at idle and operator intervention, suggesting procedural deviation rather than mechanical failure (disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE).
